description:
Haliotis cracherodii, commonly known as the black abalone, is a species of sea snail, a marine gastropod mollusk in the family Haliotidae, the abalones.

The black abalone is found along the western coast of North America, ranging from Oregon to Baja California in Mexico. It typically inhabits rocky intertidal and subtidal zones, clinging to the substrate using its large and muscular foot.

The shell of the black abalone is usually black or dark gray in color, oval-shaped, and has a series of respiratory pores along the left side. The interior of the shell is iridescent and nacre-lined. The foot of the black abalone is large and powerful, allowing it to firmly attach to the rocks and resist being dislodged by waves and currents.

Black abalone are herbivorous, feeding primarily on various species of macroalgae and kelp. They play an important ecological role in their coastal habitats, contributing to the overall diversity and functioning of the rocky intertidal ecosystem.

Unfortunately, the black abalone has been facing significant population declines in recent decades due to a combination of factors, including disease, overharvesting, and environmental stressors. As a result, it is considered a threatened species and is the subject of conservation efforts to protect and restore its populations.
